channel.title: excerpt on rs.io
channel.description: Recent content in excerpt on rs.io

item.title: “The Ask” is an Entrepreneur’s Core Skill
item.description:
+ Other Notes on Entrepreneurial Expertise

I’ve been going through the second edition of the Cambridge Handbook of Expertise after reading the first years ago, and was delighted to find the new edition has a chapter on excellence among entrepreneurs.

Some highlights:

item.title: Math Jokes
item.description: The AMS has a 2005 paper “Foolproof: A Sampling of Mathematical Folk Humor” which is — delightfully — filled with math jokes.

item.title: Hal Abelson on Math for Programmers
item.description: Seibel: So that explains why the book is the way it is.

item.title: It Probably Won A Prize
item.description: Architect Sam Sloan coordinated a project in which employees … were able to select their own office furniture and plan office layout … Since both the Seattle and Los Angeles branches of the FAA were scheduled to move into new buildings at about the same time, the client for the project, the General Services Administration, agreed with architect Sloan’s proposal to involve employees in the design process in Seattle, while leaving the Los Angeles office as a control condition where traditional methods of space planning would be followed.

item.title: Why Dogs Bark At Night
item.description: A reformed thief, telling of his success, put it this way, “I’m telling you, if I had a hundred dollars for every time I heard a dog owner tell their dog to ‘shut up and go lie down’ while I was right outside their window, I’d be a millionaire.

item.title: Zach Weinersmith On The Importance Of Reading Books
item.description: Zach Weinersmith writes Saturday Morning Breakfast Cereal, my current favorite webcomic.

item.title: You Could Have Discovered Quantum Mechanics
item.description: Quantum mechanics is what you would inevitably come up with if you started from probability theory, and then said, let’s try to generalize it so that the numbers we used to call “probabilities” can be negative numbers.

item.title: Statistician on a Plane Joke
item.description: Speaking of probability and statistics, there is the story of a statistician who told a friend that he never took airplanes: “I have computed the probability that there will be a bomb on the plane,” he explained, “and although this probability is low, it is still too high for my comfort.

item.title: Bill Thurston on Reading Hard Things
item.description: I was really amazed by my first encounters with serious mathematics textbooks.

item.title: Two Cultures of Number Theorists
item.description: There is a famous distinction in prime number theory between the number theorists who like to multiply primes, and the number theorists who like to add primes.

item.title: Feynman on Reading Difficult Things
item.description: Well, I asked him, “How can I read it? It’s so hard.

item.title: Scott Aaronson on Mathematics
item.description: From Luke’s recent interview of Scott Aaronson (theoretical compsci guy at MIT, who blogs here):

item.title: Feynman on the Supernatural
item.description: The nurse recorded the time of death, 9:21 P.M. He discovered, oddly, that the clock had halted at that moment —just the sort of mystical phenomenon that appealed to unscientific people.

item.title: Sir John Harington on Treason
item.description: I thought about titling this as “Sir John Harington on Selection Effects,” but treason seemed more compelling.

item.title: Thurston on Confusion
item.description: Mathematics is a process of staring hard enough with enough perseverance at at the fog of muddle and confusion to eventually break through to improved clarity.

item.title: No, I Love You More
item.description: Kaprio, Koskenvuo, and Rita (1987) noted that in the week following the death of a spouse, suicide rates are elevated almost tenfold for women, and almost seventyfold for men.

item.title: Let Them Eat Lobster
item.description: Prior to [the mid-19th century], lobster was considered a mark of poverty or as a food for indentured servants or lower members of society in Maine, Massachusetts, and the Canadian Maritimes, and servants specified in employment agreements that they would not eat lobster more than twice per week.
